title: FACTBOX-Cricket-New Zealand v England test series
text: March 20, 2018 / 8:01 AM / Updated 19 minutes ago FACTBOX-Cricket-New Zealand v England test series Reuters Staff 4 Min Read WELLINGTON, March 20 (Reuters) - A two-test series between New Zealand and England begins at Eden Park in Auckland on Thursday: FIXTURES (start times GMT): 1st test - March 22-26, Auckland (0100) 2nd test - March 30-April 3, Christchurch (2200) NEW ZEALAND Captain: Kane Williamson Coach: Mike Hesson Squad: Jeet Raval, Tom Latham, Kane Williamson, Ross Taylor, Henry Nicholls, Colin de Grandhomme, BJ Watling, Todd Astle, Tim Southee, Matt Henry, Neil Wagner, Trent Boult, Martin Guptill Recent form: Beat West Indies 2-0 at home Lost South Africa 1-0 at home Beat Bangladesh 2-0 at home Beat Pakistan 2-0 at home Lost India 3-0 away Captain: Joe Root Coach: Trevor Bayliss Squad: Alastair Cook, Mark Stoneman, James Vince, Joe Root, Dawid Malan, Ben Stokes, Jonny Bairstow, Moeen Ali, Chris Woakes, Stuart Broad, Mark Wood, Jimmy Anderson, Liam Livingstone, Mason Crane, Craig Overton, Ben Foakes Recent form: Beat West Indies 2-1 at home Beat South Africa 3-1 at home Lost India 4-0 away 2015 - New Zealand won by 199 runs Leeds 2015 - England won by 124 runs London 2013 - England won by 247 runs Leeds 2013 - England won by 170 runs London 2013 - Match drawn Auckland 2008 - England won by innings & nine runs Nottingham 2008 - England won by six wickets Manchester 2008 - Match drawn London FIRST TEST Eden Park, Auckland - Capacity: 50,000 Originally a drained swamp, it became a sports ground in 1900 and has been the home of Auckland cricket since 1910 and Auckland rugby since 1925. It is also the site of the infamous flour bomb rugby test between South Africa and New Zealand in 1981 and where the hosts collapsed to the lowest test cricket score of 26 against England in 1955. While a dual-purpose venue it has become more of a specialised rugby ground with the construction of stands for the 2011 Rugby World Cup creating a strange configuration for cricket with short boundaries behind square and straight down the ground. Has fallen out of favour as a test venue in recent years, having hosted just 10 matches in the last 20 years and two in the last decade, with New Zealand Cricket preferring the boutique-sized grounds in Hamilton, Dunedin, Christchurch and Wellington. Its floodlights and large capacity, however, make it ideal as the venue for the countryâ€™s first day-night test. MATCH OFFICIALS Umpires: Bruce Oxenford, Paul Reiffel (both Australia) TV official: Marais Erasmus (South Africa) Fourth official: Wayne Knights (New Zealand) Match referee: Richie Richardson (West Indies) HISTORY Previous New Zealand v England tests in Auckland Matches: 16
